content: <articles>    <article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink/">   <front>     <article-meta>       <title-group>         <article-title>Heat Transfer and Wave Measurements in the Baltic Sea: Principle, Setup and Plan for SOPRAN II</article-title>       </title-group>       <contrib-group>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Nagel</surname>             <given-names>Leila</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, University of Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Kiefhaber</surname>             <given-names>Daniel</given-names>           </name> <name>             <surname>Rocholz</surname>             <given-names>Roland</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, University of Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Balschbach</surname>             <given-names>G\ufffd\ufffdnther</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, University of Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>J\ufffd\ufffdhne</surname>             <given-names>Bernd</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, University of Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Schimpf</surname>             <given-names>Uwe</given-names>           </name>           <aff>             <institution>Institute of Environmental Physics, University of Heidelberg, Germany</institution>           </aff>         </contrib>       </contrib-group>       <pub-date pub-type="pub">         <year>2011</year>       </pub-date>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/12602"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/12602/files/DPG2011_ACFT_Poster.pdf"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/12602/files/DPG2011_ACFT_Poster.png?subformat=icon-90"/>     </article-meta>     <abstract><p>Heat is used as a proxy tracer for gases to study the transport processes<br /> across the sea-surface interface to obtain a detailed insight into<br /> the diffusive and turbulent processes controlling the transport. A carbon<br /> dioxide laser forces a periodically varying heat flux density onto<br /> the water surface and the amplitude damping and phase shift of the<br /> sea surface temperature is measured from infrared image sequences.<br /> The transport process can be treated by linear system theory and the<br /> relation between the input signal (periodically varying surface flux density)<br /> and the output (surface temperature) is estimated. Within the<br /> framework of the SOPRAN initiative three field experiments in the<br /> Baltic Sea were conducted. The locally derived heat transfer rates are<br /> scaled to gas transfer rates, which are in good agreement with empirical<br /> gas transfer wind speed relationships for moderate winds speeds.<br /> At high wind speed, the transfer rates are lower, which is explained<br /> by the fact that heat transport is insensitive to bubble-mediated gas<br /> transfer, i.e. it measures only a part of the transfer process directly at<br /> the water surface.</p></abstract>   </front>   <article-type>user-asi</article-type> </article>   </articles>
